data.title: copy paste doesn't work in integrated console
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.1
- OS Version: windows

data.title: unregister handler for the 'type' command.
data.body:
Feature request: provide an API to unregister a handler for the 'type' command.

If an extension only needs to register the 'type' for specific scenarios (e.g. only some editors), it is forced to handle it all the time and call 'default:type' to delegate back to vscode.

However, even a handler that immediately delegates back to 'default:type' introduces a lot of lag, and can cause characters to be entered out of order w.r.t. non-'type' editing commands like cursor movement, paste, etc.

data.title: Follow and watch settings.json single-level symlinks
data.body:
Fixes #8547

---

Not sure how it ever worked looking at the commit history, this works though. Couldn't find an option to give to the watcher.

data.title: #55: Batch results for IPC
data.body: Speeds up file search, especially under Windows. On my Windows machine with 224k results, the duration until the unsorted results were available for fuzzy-sorting went from ~35s down to ~13s. (On my OS X machine it went from ~15s down to ~13s.)

data.title: Remove terminal focus command
data.body:
Fixes #9293 

---

@bpasero the deprecation stuff fine to bring back? Also it should probably say

> Command workbench.action.terminal.focus **has been removed**`...

Since deprecation means it still works but will be removed eventually.

data.title: Make the editor toolbar buttons configurable

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Arch

Split editor has a dedicated button at the top-right of the editor. That functionality has never been a button I want. What I really do want very frequently though, is a move-editor-right button in that same place.
It would be nice if we could configure the button(/s) in that location.

data.title: API support to cancel showInputBox
data.body:
Feature request: API support to cancel `showInputBox`. E.g. add a `vscode.CancellationToken` to its options.

Example use case: I've implemented a custom text search, using the `validateInput` option to update the search as the user types. Certain events cancel the search, in which case, the input box should disappear.

data.title: showInputBox overwrites input with initial value when validation fails
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0, 1.4.0 commit 4d0b2f5
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:

``` typescript
export function activate(activationContext: vscode.ExtensionContext) {
  vscode.window.showInputBox({
    value: 'initial-value',
    validateInput: (text: string) => text=='' ? '' : 'input must be empty'
  });
}
```
1. run the above extension
2. type a character into the input box
3. this will trigger validation failure
4. **bug:** the typed text will be replaced with the initial value
5. subsequent characters will not be replaced by the initial value
6. clear the text (satisfying validation and removing the error)
7. go to step 2 to repeat.

data.title: Ability to scroll build output to first issue.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  1.4.0-Insider
- OS Version:
  OSX 10.11.5

With a basic `make` task, pressing the build keystroke causes output on the integrated terminal, which scrolls to the bottom. This is sane default behavior, but given that the terminal already autolinks to files in error lines (which by the way is absolutely fantastic!), it would be wonderful if it could scroll to the first error line.

My reasoning is that for a stream of build errors, it is best to address the first one by default, which is the least likely to be a spurious or secondary error.

Is it possible to configure a scrolling behavior for the integrated terminal, either as part of the task or perhaps a keystroke?

As always, thanks for the great work!

data.title: Add support for filtering the explore pane via type-ahead search

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.4.0-insider (1.4.0-insider)`
- OS Version: `OS X El Capitan Version 10.11.5`

It would be great to have on-demand filtering the explorer pane to reduce the "noise" when working on a subset of files. For example, I usually work with VSCode open to the root of our repo (with many projects in it) and I am lately finding myself needing to update common things across the projects (say in package.json, project.json, etc), so right now I have to either scroll around in the explorer pane or use Goto->File -- which forces me to have to type the file name in over an over. If I could just filter the explorer pane to show all project.json files it would be quick and painless.

Thanks!

data.title: Allow to search commands by keybinding in command palette

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.4.0-insider (4d0b2f5f15bf7011d3a99888763a7b46a5953d95, 2016-07-15T12:35:33.467Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14372

Discovered the want for this when I typed Ctrl+B instead of Ctrl+V and triggered the Toggle Sidebar Visibility command . I wanted to know what command I had invoked so I could remember it in the future and I tried to search for Ctrl+B in the command palette but nothing came up.

Would like to be able to search for commands by hotkey to improve discoverability of exactly what happens when I sometimes type the wrong hotkey.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16890726/0e058cbe-4aa6-11e6-9fe8-1a8c9d5cff1d.png)

data.title: Generate complete list of keybindings 'command' and 'when' values.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  1.4.0-Insider
- OS Version:
  OSX 10.11.5

I would like to be able to get a json file listing all possible commands, and for each one, the valid "when" values. My reason for this is that I want to write a validator for my keybindings, so that when I edit them I know when I make a typo.

If this already exists, then perhaps we could discuss how to document it better?

If the default keybindings are guaranteed to contain all commands, then that's a start, but the user is still left guessing what the valid "when" values are.

Ideally, this would be exposed as a menu item right below "Keyboard Shortcuts", but I could live with it being a script in the repo. Totally open to other suggestions as well.

Lastly, if this seems valuable, we might also consider doing something similar for settings.

Thanks!

data.title: Intellisense and CodeLens not working with Unity
data.body:
- VSCode Version:   **1.3.1**
- OS Version:  **Linux Mint 18**

Steps to Reproduce:
following basic steps provided here: 

http://www.gamasutra.com/blogs/SimonJackson/20160125/264182/Debugging_Unity_3D_with_VSCode.php

as well as mostly (stale?) documentation here:

https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/runtimes/unity

install Visual Studio Code
install / enable debugging for Unity plugin in VSC
install / enable "legacy c#" plugin in VSC for use with Unity (as newer C# is only dotnet core 1.0)
create Unity project..  add dotBunny asset, enable integration, then "open c# in vs code" in Unity...  

no intellisense nor codelens at all   >.<  (sad puppies and kittens are crying)

data.title: Go to file - add option to exclude symbols
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.5

When navigating to "Open Files and Global Symbols by name", I'm nearly always looking for a file.  Having symbols there adds duplicate results that are very rarely relevant, and slows things down.  Searching for MyClass usually comes up with:
- MyClass.cs (99% the thing I'm looking for)
- The class definition
- Usually some public properties that I've never found a use for navigating to

I'm also hoping that if there were an option to exclude symbols, we could have a lightning fast go to file like Sublime, instead of the search getting bogged down looking through some symbols database.

Thanks!

data.title: Step Over jumps to end of function when debugging TypeScript that uses async/await
data.body:
**Environment**
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insider
- OS Version: Mac
- TypeScript Version: 2.0

**Steps to Reproduce**
1. Set a break point on a line of TypeScript code in an async function that uses the await keyword on the Promise result of another async function. Example:`const result = await doSomethingAsync(); console.log(result);`
2. Start debugging in VS Code by selecting a related launch profile in a TypScript project. See my example snippet below.
3. Run necessary code so that the debugger is stopped on the breakpoint from step 1.
4. Press F10 to step over the `doSomethingAsync` function.

**Example**

``` javascript
class Foo {
   async do() {
     console.log('before');
     const result = await doSomethingAsync(); //<= set breakpoint here
     console.log('after', result); // <= hit F10 and notice it doesn't go here
   }
}
```

**Expected Result**
It would proceed to the `console.log('after', result);`

**Actual Result**
It jumps the end of the function. In order to debug, you have to put a breakpoint on every like inside that async function.

This issue was discussed [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4798) regarding step into and was resolved by @weinand but did not address the jump issue after testing the new fix.

**Demo**
- Pull [petstore](https://github.com/swimlane/node-microservice-demo/tree/master/petstore)
- Set a breakpoint [here](https://github.com/swimlane/node-microservice-demo/blob/master/petstore/src/controllers/PetStoreController.ts#L28)
- Run Launch in VSCode
- Goto `localhost:8080/pets` in your browser and observe as you step into and over each function.

**Further Details**
The issue actually presents itself in both TypeScript and Babel situations. This issue has been raised to Source Map team, Babel, Mozilla, Chrome Debugging and to TC39. See:
- https://github.com/mozilla/source-map/issues/221
- http://discuss.babeljs.io/t/async-await-debugging-issues/132
- https://github.com/tc39/ecmascript-asyncawait/issues/93
- https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1238745

Chrome debugger claims to have support for this now - https://twitter.com/addyosmani/status/740155716401565696

data.title: Auto Update Extensions

data.title: better javascript/Node.js/es6 syntax highlighting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:31:10.994Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.5.0

**Motivation**
It seems that nobody deeply cares about Javascript/Nodejs syntax highlighting. VSCode does a better job then other text editors (e.g. Atom) but it's not perfect. VSC could be the #1 choise for javascript developers if some common syntax highlighting bugs were fixed.

**Steps to Reproduce**

Example 1:

``` js
let from = neki;
from = a; // is a variable and should be in white color like other variables
```

Example 2:

``` js
exports.myVar = async (ctx, next) => {} // this is all in white but exports and async should be e.g. in red or blue
```

Example 3:

``` js
t.me = 1;
t.is = 2; // `is` is in blue but should be the same color as the above (1)
t.in = 3; // `in` is in blue but should be the same color as the above (1)
t.of = 4; // `of` is in blue but should be the same color as the above (1)
```

data.title: Lua commenting using // doesn't actually comment
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)

Visual Studio Code does not automatically comment in Lua using // but it really should.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a *.lua file
2. Type "// I am really commented text but VSCode doesn't show it."

data.title: TypeScript Syntax highlighting doesn't work in a function has a return type that ends in a number
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a class that ends in a number.
2. In that class, create a function and specify the return type as the name of the class you just created.
3. Notice how syntax highlighting breaks in that function.

Notice how "return this" is black in the function that has a return type that ends in a number.
![tssyntaxhighlightingbug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7350617/16884398/20f60844-4a97-11e6-9099-f00811e0970a.png)

data.title: [cli] RFE: Opening file.go:47 should go to line 47 automatically
data.body:
Opening file from terminal using `$ code -r ./file.go:47` should go to line 47 automatically.

This feature would be much appreciated when developing on Linux / Mac OS X. Most modern IDEs (incl. Atom and SublimeText) can do this too.

data.title: Fuzzy Intellisense only uses last typed character and is too loose
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insider (4d0b2f5f15bf7011d3a99888763a7b46a5953d95)
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start typing anything that will prompt Intellisense in C#
2. See that only the single last character entered is highlighted and used for filtering

To demonstrate, here is a gif of how it works in VSCode 1.3.1:
![vscode-1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/594564/16881524/f00e8c50-4aba-11e6-8232-9094d903b089.gif)
Note that all characters are highlighted and used for filtering

Here is a gif of latest insider build:
![vscode-2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/594564/16881558/1130aa9e-4abb-11e6-8cf4-8c558fdaa2c6.gif)
See that only the last char is highlighted and used for filtering.

data.title: Setting PowerShell version commandline switch fails

2. ctrl+` to open terminal.
3. Terminal Window crashes and goes away.

data.title: Reports that file is saved while it is not (remote location, sshfs)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.2.1 (1.2.1)
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.5 (15F34)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Mount remote harddrive with sshfs and name 'ma'
2. Open 'ma' in VS Code
3. Open a file in working files
4. Edit and save (black dot will show up and hide). Check with 'cat' that the saved version is the same as in Code.
5. Remove mount
6. Edit file and save (black dot will show up and hide)
7. Check with 'cat' that the saved version is older than in Code

data.title: markdown editor and preview ui issues
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.3.1 (1.3.1)
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4

A. Syntax highlighting fails after first backtick in second physical line of text 

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Type this text into `md` file:

```
Here is some text with 
`back-ticks` in second line and `this` won't highlight
```
1. The first back-ticked word is highlighted, but second isn't

B. md preview view looses zoom

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Preview a markdown doc via `cmd`+`shift`+`V`
2. Press `cmd`+`+` to zoom in (multiple times to see #5)
3. Click another tab
4. Click back to preview, zoom is reset
5. Pressing `cmd`+`+` zooms to one more than originally zoomed level of #2

data.title: Unable to Close Split Editor without saving or cancelling a dirty file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a File.  
2. Make revisions to the file.
3. Click the Split Editor (opening the file in two editors).
4. Close the the second Editor.
5. If you click "Don't Save" it loses the changes on the first window.
   Need a way to close a panel without saving or cancelling a save.

data.title: Integrated Terminal shows nothing

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.3.0 and 1.3.1 - OS Version: Windows 10 x64 [10586] Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open VSCode 2. `Ctrl`+` Integrated terminal didn't work after I updated to version 1.3.0 like this: ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7767960/16880205/af7593ec-4ae6-11e6-8ca9-28fc8c997b3e.png) Here is my config (I didn't change anything): ``` "terminal.external.windowsExec": "cmd", "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe" ``` After checking task manager , I find that the terminal VSCode opened is '"C:\Windows\SysWOW64\cmd.exe". It isn't the "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe".

data.title: Ability to remove file permanently (bypass trash)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X, 10.11

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open file explorer.
2. Select a file.
3. Choose "Delete" from the contex menu or hit ⌘+Delete.

You'll be prompted to move the file to Trash. It'd be nice to have an ability (with a separate shortcut or by switching an IDE option in the config) to remove files permanently.
